docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A2-7 Missile Attack in Jordan Misses U.S. Navy Vessels A rocket attack missed two United States Navy vessels docked at the Red Sea port city of Aqaba, Jordan, killing one Jordanian soldier and hitting the nearby Israeli town of Eilat. The assault raised fears that militants tied to Iraq's insurgency were operating in Jordan. A1 Al Qaeda Conviction in Germany A Moroccan man brought to trial in connection with the Sept. 11 attacks was convicted when a German court found him guilty of belonging to a terrorist organization and sentenced him to seven years in prison. A6 Sunni Election Workers Killed A group of Sunni election workers in the northern city of Mosul were kidnapped and then killed in front of a crowded mosque, the latest in a series of violent incidents revealing the rift that has opened in Iraq's Sunni community over whether to participate in the coming elections. A5 16th Gaza Settlement Cleared Israeli soldiers and police officers broke past burning roadblocks to clear out the Gadid settlement. That left just 5 of the original 21 Gaza settlements with residents remaining after three days of a forced evacuation that has proceeded with less turmoil than almost anyone had predicted. A3 Polio Restrictions in Mecca Saudi Arabia, which gets millions of visitors each year making their pilgrimage to Mecca, has ordered all young visitors from countries with polio cases to bring proof of vaccination, the World Health Organization announced. A7 Plans Made for Afghan Elections American and Afghan commanders have prepared security plans for the September national elections in Afghanistan. They call for local forces to provide protection at 6,000 polling stations while foreign troops stand by as reinforcements. A5 NATIONAL A8-11; 14 Patient Waiting Increases As Health Care Improves Health care researchers say the problem of patient waiting has only become significantly worse in the last 10 years as advances in technology have created more tests and procedures to wait for, and new drugs and treatments mean more people need more visits to a doctor. A1 Panel Hears of Rape in Prison The National Prison Rape Elimination Commission, which has been investigating the prevalence, cause and possible solutions to prison rape, heard testimony from six victims who gave disturbing accounts of their ordeals. A8 Frist Backs Intelligent Design Senator Bill Frist of Tennessee, the Republican leader, aligned himself with President Bush when he said that intelligent design as well as evolution should be taught in public schools. A10 F.E.C. Fines Friends of DeLay Westar Energy Inc., a Kansas electric utility entangled in investigations surrounding Representative Tom DeLay, and three men who worked for the company will pay $40,500 in fines to settle accusations of improper fund-raising, the Federal Election Commission says. A10 Roberts's Reagan Years A survey of tens of thousands of pages of documents released by the National Archives makes it clear that for four years in the 1980's, John G. Roberts Jr. was like a legal air-traffic controller in the Reagan White House: almost every issue of any importance crossed his radar screen. A10 Judges Critical of Wildlife Staff Federal judges on opposite sides of the country ruled that the Fish and Wildlife Service had acted arbitrarily and violated the Endangered Species Act when it reversed its own decisions and cut back on protections for two disparate species. A14 NEW YORK/REGION B1-5 Judge's DisappearanceIs Revisited 75 Years Later The death of a 91-year-old woman in Bellrose, Queens, this year, and notes she left to be read by her family upon her death, prompted New York City police detectives to reinvestigate the disappearance of a State Supreme Court justice, as a murder -- one perhaps authored by a city policeman and his brother. A1 9/11 Audio Engulfs Families A small but growing number of relatives of Sept. 11 victims have been delving into a vast trove of oral histories, Fire Department dispatch tapes and 911 phone logs that was released by New York City last week. Some have uncovered priceless nuggets of intelligence, while others have found new fuel for their anger: evidence that they say reveals failures that cost lives. B1 Fossil Hidden in Plain Sight When Brooklyn College started renovating its lecture halls in May, scientists began packing what they had assumed was a plaster cast. To their astonishment, they discovered authentic dinosaur tracks that had been covered over for decades because the staff believed it was a worthless replica. B1 Beliefs B5 ARTS B7-17 OBITUARIES C16 SPORTSSATURDAY D1-7 College Players in Transition College quarterbacks are on the move. Of the Division I football programs that ended the 2004 season ranked in the top 25, 16 had quarterbacks either transfer, leave the college before their eligibility was up or switch to another position. D1 BUSINESS DAY C1-13 Merck Liable in Vioxx Trial In the first verdict of a Vioxx-related personal-injury lawsuit, a Texas jury found the drug's maker, Merck, liable and awarded $253.5 million to the widow of Robert Ernst, who died in 2001 after taking the painkiller. The size of the award may have implications for future Vioxx lawsuits. A1 Mechanics Strike at Northwest Mechanics at Northwest Airlines walked off the job after their union and the airline failed to agree on the company's demand for $176 million in wage and benefit cuts. The strike was the first major labor disruption in the airline industry since 1998. A1 Oil Prices And Markets Fall News from Wal-Mart and other retailers that rising gasoline prices were cutting into their sales was enough to offset what benefit there might have been from a 2.2 percent drop in the price of crude oil. C6 Business Digest C2 EDITORIAL A12-13 Editorials: United States of emergency; the oil effect; how financiers politic in New Jersey; intelligent design and the Smithsonian. Columns: Maureen Dowd, John Tierney. Bridge B16 TV Listings B17 Crossword B14 Weather D8

docs.lead_paragraph: Three years ago the Bush administration began prodding countries to shield Americans from the fledgling International Criminal Court in The Hague, which was intended to be the first permanent tribunal for prosecuting crimes like genocide. The United States has since cut aid to some two dozen nations that refused to sign immunity agreements that American officials say are intended to protect American soldiers and policy makers from politically motivated prosecutions.

headline.main: Bush's Aid Cuts On Court Issue Roil Neighbors

docs.abstract: Bush administration has cut aid to two dozen countries for refusing to sign agreements to shield Americans from any prosecution at new International Criminal Court at The Hague; administration feels United States, with its military might stretched across globe, is uniquely vulnerable to politically motivated prosecutions; cuts are generating strong resentment, particularly in Latin America and Caribbean, home to 12 nations that have been penalized, where many see cuts as heavy-handed diplomacy; some Americans are also beginning to question policy, as political and military leaders in region complain that aid cuts are squandering good will and hurting their ability to cooperate in other important areas, like campaigns against drugs and terrorism; most of penalties have been in form of cuts in military training and other security aid; budget bill passed in Dec also permits new cuts in social and health-care programs; their loss is being sorely felt in small countries; photo; map (M)
docs.snippet: Aid cuts for countries that refused to shield Americans from the International Criminal Court are generating resentment.

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: WAR CRIMES, GENOCIDE AND CRIMES AGAINST HUMANITY

docs.lead_paragraph: Mary Duffy was lying in bed half-asleep on the morning after her breast cancer surgery in February when a group of white-coated strangers filed into her hospital room. Without a word, one of them -- a man -- leaned over Ms. Duffy, pulled back her blanket, and stripped her nightgown from her shoulders.

headline.main: In the Hospital, a Degrading Shift From Person to Patient

docs.abstract: First article in series, Being a Patient, explores often degrading experience of entering medical system, whether hospital, nursing home or clinic; in surveys, many people who have received medical care say they benefit from expertise of first-rate doctors, but often feel resentful, helpless and dehumanized in process; they cite impersonal nature of care; anthropologists say transformation from citizen to patient can be jarring, and it begins immediately at admission with clerk handing out confusing forms, and newly designated 'patient' required to strip to underwear and don flimsy hospital gown that opens at back; says it continues with nearly total lack of privacy during hospital stay; many patients complain about nurses and doctors who enter room and begin examination or medical procedure without introducing themselves or speaking at all; many patients complain about noise on most hospital floors; photos (L)
docs.snippet: Within the medical system, the small courtesies of life are often neglected precisely when they are needed most.

multimedia.credit: Within the medical system, the small courtesies of life are often neglected precisely when they are needed most.
multimedia.caption: For Patients, a Loss of Dignity

legacy.MultimediaSummary1: Within the medical system, the small courtesies of life are often neglected precisely when they are needed most.
legacy.MultimediaHeadline1: For Patients, a Loss of Dignity

docs.lead_paragraph: Patients arrive broke, busted or abandoned at our methadone clinic in a raw section of Northeast Washington. They are opiate addicts, primarily dependent on heroin, though some take vast doses of street-bought painkillers like OxyContin. Drinking the pink methadone solution every day prevents withdrawal sickness.

headline.main: A Whiff of 'Reefer Madness' in U.S. Drug Policy

docs.snippet: Why is marijuana, of all drugs, the main target of the White House Office of National Drug Control Policy?
